nz.govt.natlib.adapter
Class DataAdapter

java.lang.Object
  nz.govt.natlib.adapter.DataAdapter
Direct Known Subclasses:
ArcAdapter, BitmapAdapter, DefaultAdapter, DocAdapter, ExcelAdapter, FlacAdapter, GIFAdapter, HTMLAdapter, ID3TagLibMP3Adapter, JpgAdapter, MP3Adapter, MPEG4Adapter, OpenOfficeAdapter, PDFAdapter, PDFBoxAdapter, PowerPointAdapter, TIFFAdapter, WarcAdapter, WaveAdapter, WordAdapter, WPAdapter, XMLAdapter, XMLAdapter3
public abstract class DataAdapter
extends java.lang.Object

Subclasses of the DataAdapter are responsible for extracting metadata out of file. To parse a new type of file, you will need to create a subclass.

Version:
1.0
Author:
Nic Evans

Constructor Detail

DataAdapter

public DataAdapter()
Method Detail

ignoreFileExtension

public void ignoreFileExtension(boolean flag)
Sets a flag to indicate that the acceptsFile() needs to ignore the file extension when deciding whether a given adapter can accept the file.

Parameters:
flag - New value of the ignoreFileExtension to set.

acceptsFile

public abstract boolean acceptsFile(java.io.File file)
This method tests whether this is adapter wants to attempt to extract metadata from this file. The standard adapters test for a file extension match, and then make additional tests to increase the confidence of getting the right type. These extra tests may involve checking header bytes or looking for particular sequences of characters in the file. This method may make use of the checkFileHeader(File,String) helper method.

Parameters:
file - The file to test.
Returns:
True if this adapter will attempt to extract the metadata from the file.

adapt

public abstract void adapt(java.io.File file,
                           ParserContext out)
                    throws java.io.IOException
This method adapts the file given into the outputstream - the results that are placed into the output stream should be in XML format.

Throws:
java.io.IOException - if there are errors reading the file.

getOutputType

public abstract java.lang.String getOutputType()
Return the DTD of the native metadata file this DataAdapter produces. Subclasses should hard-code this method to return the name of that DTD.

Returns:
The filename of the DTD.

getInputType

public abstract java.lang.String getInputType()
Return the MimeType of the type of file this adapter "adapts". For standard adapters this should return the MIME type of the input file. Subclasses will, in general, hard-code this value.

Returns:
the MIME Type.

getMimeType

public java.lang.String getMimeType(java.io.File file)
Gets the MIME type of the file being adapted. The default is to return the input type.

Parameters:
file - The file to get the MIME type for.
Returns:
The MIME type of the file.

getName

public abstract java.lang.String getName()
Get the name of the adapter.

Returns:
The name of the adapter.

public abstract java.lang.String getDescription()
Gets a description of the adapter.

Returns:
The description of the adapter.

getVersion

public abstract java.lang.String getVersion()
Returns the version of the adapter.

Returns:
The version of the adapter.

writeFileInfo

public final void writeFileInfo(java.io.File file,
                                ParserContext out)
                         throws java.io.IOException
This method extracts the basic file meta data from the file, including filename, path, and file attributes. This method should be called within the adapt(File,ParserContext) method of subclasses.

Parameters:
file - The file to extract meta data from.
out - The parser context.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if there are errors gathering the metadata.

toHexFilter

public static java.lang.String toHexFilter(java.lang.String asciiString)

checkFileHeader

public static boolean checkFileHeader(java.io.File file,
                                      java.lang.String test)
Helper method for testing a file header. This method can be used as part of the acceptsFile(File) method.

Parameters:
file - The file to test.
test - A space separated string of hex bytes that will be at the start of a file. To skip bytes in the header, use "xx". As an example, the WaveAdapter uses the string "52 49 46 46 xx xx xx xx 57 41 56 45 66 6D 74 20".
Returns:
true if the string is at the start of the file. False is it isn't or if there are any exceptions accessing/parsing the file.
